New Records: The Dodgers achieved the largest shutout win in Dodgers playoff history with an 8-0 victory.
Key Match Events: Mookie Betts hit a solo home run during Game 4 against the Padres in San Diego.
Shohei Ohtani drove a ball down the right-field line at about 1,000 mph.
Will Smith blasted another weak pitch over the center-field fence, one dugout dancing, the other one sulking — game over.
The Dodgers were forced to navigate with no starter and all bullpen in Game 4.
Ohtani was thrown out at home after daringly speeding around third on a sharp grounder.
The Padres haven't scored in 15 innings dating to the second inning of Game 3.
Pre-Game Insights: The Dodgers were so loose during pregame workouts that they played mini golf in the clubhouse.
Mookie Betts said they weren't uptight, they were having fun, laughing, joking. They knew what they were about to do.
The Dodgers predicted they could hit Padres starter Dylan Cease on short rest.
Teoscar Hernández said they would make him work.
Post-Match Reflections: Dodgers manager Dave Roberts said the team's response to their adversity was impressive.
Roberts said it's a street fight in the postseason, and for him to see their guys go through what they've been through and respond the way they have really makes him excited about Game 5.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The series opener featured a monster first punch by the home-run-hitting Ohtani.
The second game was filled with showboating Padres who taunted bottle-throwing fans.
The Padres want to steal this National League Division series again? This time they’re going to have to do it in a winner-take-all game at Dodger Stadium.
Others: The winner of this game likely will be the favorite to not only advance to the World Series but also win it.
The series will come down to one game, one night, one more bit of drama.
The Dodgers have one more chance, one more moment, one more game.
